content.text: Fig. 1.2 shows the reading on the stop-watch
Record, in Table 1.1, the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations
Calculate and record in Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation
Calculate \(T^2\) and record your value in Table 1.1
Write the units in the column headings
The distance \(d\) is measured from the bottom of the clamp to the centre of the bob
The student adjusts the length of the pendulum until \(d = 50.0 \text{cm}\)
He displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings
He uses a stop-watch to measure the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations
The student repeats the procedure in **(a)** using \(d = 100.0 \text{cm}\). The readings and results are shown in Table 1.1
Another student suggests that \(T^2\) is directly proportional to \(d\)
Explain briefly how to test the suggestion using the results in Table 1.1
The procedure can be repeated to plot a graph
Suggest additional values of \(d\) that are suitable for the experiment
Explain how you would measure the distance \(d\) as accurately as possible. Draw a diagram to help your explanation
Explain why timing 10 oscillations gives a more accurate result for the period \(T\) than timing one oscillation
A student investigates the period of a pendulum
Fig. 1.1 shows the set-up
Write down the current \(I\)
Record the potential difference \(V\) reading in the first row of Table 2.1
The student places a sliding contact \(\mathbf{S}\) at a distance \(l = 40.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\)
She measures the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the length \(l\) of the resistance wire
She measures the current \(I\) in the circuit
The meters are shown in Fig. 2.2 and Fig. 2.3
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the values of resistance \(R\) using the equation
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
The student repeats the procedure in (a) using \(l = 50.0 \text{cm}, 60.0 \text{cm}, 70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(80.0 \text{cm}\)
The readings are shown in Table 2.1
Plot a graph of \(R\) (y-axis) against \(V\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0)
Draw the best-fit line
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
G =
A student investigates the resistance of a wire
Fig. 2.1 shows the circuit used
The thermometer in Fig. 3.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
Write the times in the first column of Table 3.1
Complete the column headings in Table 3.1
The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. He places the thermometer in the water
He records the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). He immediately starts a stop-watch
He records the temperature at 30s intervals. The temperature readings are shown in Table 3.1
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) between time \(t = 0\) and time \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
\(\Delta \theta_{1} =\)
Calculate the difference in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{\mathrm{S}}\) between the temperature at time \(t = 0\) and room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\Delta \theta_{\mathrm{S}} =\)
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{2}\) between time \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and time \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
\(\Delta \theta_{2} =\)
Calculate the difference in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{\mathrm{T}}\) between the temperature at time \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\Delta \theta_{\mathrm{T}} =\)
State whether the results agree with this suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to the results
statement
justification
Suggest how you would continue the experiment, using the same apparatus and method, to investigate the suggestion
A student suggests that the decrease in temperature of the water in \(90 \text{s}\) should be greater when the starting temperature is greater
Refer to Table 3.1. Estimate the temperature of the water in the beaker after cooling for a further 90 s
A student investigates the cooling of water under different conditions
Fig. 3.1 shows the set-up
A student investigates the effect of changing the colour of light on the focal length of a lens
The focal length \(f\) of a lens is given by the equation \(f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)
The distance \(u\) is the distance between an object and the lens. The distance \(v\) is the distance between the lens and the image that is formed on a screen
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of changing the colour of light on the focal length of a lens
The following apparatus is available to the student:
illuminated object
a selection of coloured filters to change the colour of the light
converging lens
screen
metre ruler
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used
In your plan, you should:
draw a labelled diagram to show the arrangement of the apparatus
explain briefly how you would do the investigation, including the measurements you would take
draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
state how you would use your results to reach a conclusion
